Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Lift Generation in a Functionalized Supra Molecular Porous Layer, From Red Cells to Super Lubrication

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of the proposed research is on the investigation of lubrication effects at the boundary of a soft porous medium when it is compressed under flow. This phenomenon is often called super lubrication, because the friction loss is dramatic. The project is inspired by the frictionless motion of the red blood cells over the endothelial glycocalyx layer (EGL) that covers the inner surface of our blood vessels. Theoretical analysis, based on detailed experiments will be pursued that can lead to the design of a new type of bearing that would utilize super lubrication with vastly increased hydrodynamic lift and reduced drag.


It is proposed to perform a systematic study to investigate fluid flow and lift generation inside random soft porous media of different scales under rapid compaction. These porous layers range from macro-scale synthetic fibers to micron-scale functionalized supramolecular layers (SML). The mechanisms that provide for the structural integrity of a functionalized SML in response to fast compression and its subsequent restoration will be examined. An experimental approach will be developed to examine the lift generation and friction reduction as a planar surface glides over a soft porous layer. These objectives are integrated in a combined research plan, which involves theoretical, experimental, and computational approaches. The proposed research circumvents the extreme difficulty in performing experiments with living organisms, and provides a bio-mimetic approach to study fluid flow in a functionalized soft porous layer. It will have broad impacts on both energy efficiency for frictionless flow and for biophysical understanding of the EGL. There are plans to engage undergraduate students in research, and to leverage existing activities at Villanova University to reach out to Girl Scouts and underrepresented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Inspired by the frictionless motion of the red blood cells over the endothelial glycocalyx layer (EGL) that covers the inner surface of our blood vessels, the PI developed a unique biomimetic approach, with the assistance of modern supramolecular chemistry, to examine two fundamental problems in fluid dynamics, lift generation in soft porous media on different scales and the mechanism that determines its structural integrity. This project had significant intellectual merit in that, 1). It investigated the transport phenomena inside random soft porous media of different scales under rapid compaction. These porous layers ranged from macro-scale synthetic fibers to micron-scale functionalized supramolecular layers (SML). 2) It circumvented the extreme difficulty in performing experiments with the living organism, using a novel experimental approach to examine the lift generation and friction reduction as a planing surface glides over a soft porous layer. 3). It established a systematic framework for soft super lubrication with tremendously reduced friction loss in a comprehensive theoretical, experimental, and computational framework. This grant also had significant broader impacts. 1). it has the potential of revolutionizing the design of lubricating bearings. In particular, it could lead to a new generation of soft lubricating bearings with far greater lift forces and a much longer life. 2). It provides important insights for better understand the biophysics of the EGL which has been demonstrated to play an important role in cardiovascular systems. 3). It engaged undergraduate students in research and leveraged existing activities at Villanova University to reach out to Girl Scouts and underrepresented minority students.

The grant has led to 17 journal publications in leading scientific journals such as the Journal of Fluid Mechanics (Cover article), Physical Review Fluids, Physics of Fluids, Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials, etc. It has also led to 45 conference presentations in conferences such as the American Physical Society Division of Fluid Dynamics Annual Meeting, and numerous invited talks and seminars by the PI. The findings of this grant have also been dessiminated via the minisymposiums that the PI organized with the focus closely reltated to the funded projects. Five Ph.D students and three undergraduate students were partially supported by the grant. These students received multiple awards including the STLE (Society of Tribologists and Lubrication Engineers) scholarship, ASME IMECE Micro and Nano Forum Most Innovative Theoretical Award, Advances in Biotechnology Award, ASME IMECE NSF Student Poster Compietition Awards and Travel awards to internatonal conferences.
